description: This figure illustrates the continuous update procedure of CLODE, which uses a neural ordinary differential equation (NODE) to solve the curve adjustment problem for low-light image enhancement.  Panel (a) shows a schematic of the continuous update process, where the ODE solver iteratively refines the image until convergence.  Panel (b) details the structure of the ODE function (ODEfunc), showing its constituent parts: a noise removal module, a curve parameter estimation module, and the core ODE equation (Eq. 9) which calculates the derivative for the next step.

caption: Figure 3: Illustration of User Controllable Design. By manually changing the integration interval from -(T + ∆t) to +(T + ∆t), ours can produce results with different exposure levels.
description: This figure illustrates the user controllability feature of the proposed CLODE method. By adjusting the integration interval (T) in the ODE solver, users can control the final exposure level of the enhanced image.  The figure shows a range of exposure levels, from underexposed (-(T+∆t)) to overexposed ((T+∆t)) images, demonstrating the flexibility of the method to produce images with a desired level of exposure.

caption: Figure 7: Visual results for the ablation study of each loss function. CLODE combines five non-reference loss functions in training for producing optimal enhancement results.
description: This figure shows the results of ablation experiments on each loss function used in CLODE.  It demonstrates the impact of each loss function on the overall image enhancement quality. By removing one loss function at a time, the figure highlights the individual contribution of each component to the final result. The image shows that using all five loss functions leads to better results compared to using a subset of them. The loss functions used are spatial consistency loss, exposure loss, color constancy loss, parameter regularization loss, and noise removal loss.

caption: Figure 11: Visualization results on LOL [5]. While CLODE demonstrates superior enhancement results, user control with CLODE† produces images that more closely resemble the ground-truth image.
description: This figure shows a comparison of image enhancement results on the LOL dataset.  It compares the input low-light images to the results produced by the CLODE and CLODE† methods. CLODE† allows the user to adjust the exposure level, offering more fine-grained control over the enhancement process. The ground truth images are also included for reference, showing that CLODE†'s user-adjustable exposure level results in images that are closer in appearance to the ground truth than the results from CLODE.

caption: Figure 11: Visualization results on LOL [5]. While CLODE demonstrates superior enhancement results, user control with CLODE† produces images that more closely resemble the ground-truth image.
description: This figure shows a comparison of image enhancement results on the LOL dataset using three different methods: the input low-light image, the results from the CLODE model, the results from the CLODE† model (with user-adjustable exposure), and the ground truth image.  The results visually demonstrate that CLODE produces enhanced images, but CLODE† offers more control over the final exposure, allowing the user to adjust the output to more closely match the ground truth.

caption: Figure 13: Visualization results on SICE [35]. While CLODE demonstrates superior enhancement results, user control with CLODE† produces images that more closely resemble the ground-truth image.
description: This figure shows a comparison of image enhancement results between CLODE and CLODE+ on the SICE dataset.  The results show that CLODE provides better enhancement than CLODE+, although CLODE+ is more closely aligned with the ground truth. The figure illustrates the capabilities of both models and highlights how user control allows the user to adjust the output to better meet specific needs.

caption: Figure 10: Comparative visualization results with (a) PairLIE [13] and (b) night-enhancement [17] on LOL [5] and SICE [35]. Images are taken from LSRW [4] and SICE [35] Part2.
description: This figure compares the visual results of the proposed CLODE method with two other unsupervised low-light image enhancement methods (PairLIE and Night-Enhancement) and the ground truth.  The comparison is done on images from two benchmark datasets (LOL and SICE). It showcases the visual improvements achieved by CLODE in terms of brightness, detail preservation, and overall image quality.

caption: Figure 15: Visualization results on MSEC [49] and extracted from internet (Flickr by julochka). Even with diverse inputs of various exposures, CLODE show robust result in an unsupervised manner.
description: This figure shows the robustness of the CLODE model by testing it on images from the MSEC dataset and images found online.  Despite the wide variation in exposure levels of the input images, CLODE consistently produces well-enhanced images, demonstrating its effectiveness in handling diverse low-light conditions.
